Name: Montecassino
Description:
ARGENTINIAN MADE AND DESIGNED BOARD GAME.
a miniatures war world two board game recreating the battle of MONTECASSINO (near Rome, Italy) between the Germans and Americans. 24 soldiers for each player..and a CANNON in bronze which adds special power to each player..
a strategic tactical game for 2 - 4 wargamers

Name: "They're Off" Horse Race Game
Description: This game is a simple spin and move horse race game for two to six players There are six color keyed tracks that have the same number of spaces around the track and the horses stay in their own colored lanes. The game includes six plastic race horses, a folding board,  and a spinner. The components come in a separate small box.  Earlier version of the game came with metal horses painted in same colors as lanes on game board and included six miniature size dice in translucent green instead of spinner.

Name: 3er Schach
Description: A 3 players variation of chess, played on a special board.
Families: Series: Krone Spiele für Erwachsene (Ass / Schmidt-Spiele)

Name: Pan American World Jet Flight Game
Description:
Australian mid-sixties release.  Box art shows a Pan-Am jet flying across Sydney Harbour with the landmark Sydney Opera House conspicuously absent (it was yet to be constructed).

The game consists of a map of the world with selected major destinations connected by plane (presumably Pan-Am) routes.  Players are dealt a series of destination cards at the start of the game; all destinations must be visited before returning to the start (Sydney).

Game components are of low grade but acceptable quality - 4 generic pawns for movers, a thin cardboard gameboard that folds in three and thin cardboard destination cards.

The destination cards are mildly educational (each have stats about population, currency, languages spoken etc.) although now very dated.

Name: Spots
Description:
Simple memory-based game variant.  Cardboard discs ('spots'), each with a certain word printed on one side, are placed face down on the gameboard.  Each spot has a matching card which forms a pair; these cards are shuffled and form the draw pile for gameplay.

A turn consists of drawing a card and finding the matching spot on the gameboard.  Unmatched cards are placed face up in front of the drawer until the appropriate match is made.  Cards may be taken either from the draw pile, from in front of an opponent or from in front of the drawing player.  The player with the most matching pairs when all spots have been removed from the board is the winner.

The game has a garage theme tacked on rather loosely - the 'spots' are representative of spots found on a garage floor and many of the words on the discs relate to this theme - dirty spot, wet spot, danger spot, grease spot etc.  The gameboard is the garage floor.

Name: Crimson Skies: Wings Over Manhattan
Description: An expansion to FASA's 1998 Crimson Skies, Wings over Manhattan adds Autogyros, plus maps and scenarios for the "Empire State", a nation in the Northeastern US.

Name: Magica
Description: Who can collect the most toys? A memory game for 2-4 children of 4 years and older. In the center lies the picture cards face-down in circle. The children use the magic hat cylinder to move along the course. Whoever can guess which toys are hidden under the cards wins a picture card to collect. The player with most pieces at the end of the game wins and is the best Magorius.

Name: Stork Bingo
Description: Bingo game with words that pertain to baby such as "rattle" and "teething ring" Each Stork Bingo game comes complete with 16 cards, markers and a caller's board.

Name: Indix Junior
Description:
20 Questions is the popular panel game in which the panel ask up to 20 Questions to guess the Person, Place or Thing. This edition should be called 20 Answers because you get 150 cards with 20 answers and the players in turn ask the Reader a number, and from that clue try to guess the answer. For each attempt a chip is paid, when the Guesser gets it correct, the Reader scores the chips paid, the Guesser scores the remainder. So getting it correct early scores you loads, getting it late scores the Reader loads. The board has a scoring track and there is an element of beating the Guesser too.

This Edition is especially for kids Ages 8 - 12.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Dixit: The Dictionary Game
Description:
From  instructions: Dixit - The Dictionary Game is a unique, fast pacing, thought provoking word game for 2-4 players involving crossword style word making with an original scoring system that enables the players themselves to decide where and how a word score may be multiplied. No player  possesses letters, the choice depends on the throw of dice every time. 
There's a Collins Minigem Dictionary to act as a referee and add ingenious twists to play.
The winner is the player scoring the most points at the end of play by clever word making and shrewd usage of the changing possibilities offered by the playing circuit. Strategy and good word searching together make a winner.

Name: Conservation Game
Description:
Object of the game is to think about conservation and how we can help in a practical way. The winner is the player obtaining the highest number of points

Going around the game board players pickup counters for good deeds eg picking up litter and recycling glass and paper - and penalties are given for leaving lights or heaters on, leaving bottles around etc

Name: Futility
Description: Developed as an educational (or perhaps a tongue-in-cheek)game by Midland Insurance Co. in 1984, Futility is a game of buying and selling insurance.  Each player, or "Risk Manager",  starts out with $3,000,000.  Movement around the game board, via rolling of the die, allows for the opportunity to buy and sell insurance (certificate of insurance cards).  There are also spaces where an "occurance" ...umm, occurs.  At that time you take an "occurance card" whereupon one of your insureds has made a claim.  Hopefully you bought the right insurance and the "occurance card" does not affect you, otherwise you'll end up paying some of your (ahem) hard earned cash.  Play continues around an endless loop (similar to Monopoly, say).  Risk Managers decide at what point they choose to withdraw from the game, as the rules explain: "when frustration level or boredom so indicates."

Name: PotzKlotz
Description:
Potzklotz contains of 5 wooden cubes, a 5 x 5 board with squares and 56 cards. The cubes are set in the middle of the board, shaping one form. The players draw 5 cards each from the stack of 56 cards. On these cards are pictures of other shapes, created by the 5 cubes. If the player on turn thinks, he can rebuild the existing shape into one shape of the cards on his hand by moving only a single cube, he plays a card and tries it without turning the board and in a single trial. If he is not able to rebuild the shape, he has to draw one more card from the stack.

The player who first gets rid of all his card, wins.

There are different rules in the box, so you can vary from lighter gaming to more heavier: Without building over the border of the board, with penalty cards for mirror-shapes etc.

Potzklotz is for children up from 7, but also for grown-ups. It is pretty difficult to think three-dimensional and turning the shapes in your imagination. SO it is good math training and much fun, too.

Home Page: http://www.potzklotz.de

Name: Before I Was a Marshal I Was a Grenadier
Description:
From the cover:
Being a set of very playable recreational Wargame rules from the 1960's designed for large-scale, convention play of tactical battles of the Napoleonic Wars.

1810-1815 Brigade/Division Actions

Name: Spaghetti and Math Balls
Description:
Each player gets a spaghetti bowl game board and six meatballs. All players put their meatballs above the spaghetti pile on the big game board.

All players spin the spinner and moves the number of spaces indicated. They must answer the math problem posted on the space they land on. If they answer the math problem correctly, they get to continue their turn and spin again to move. If answered incorrectly, their turn ends and the next player's turn begins.

A player gets to put a meatball in their scoring bowl each time they pass the "Start" space. The first player to put all six meatballs into his or her bowl wins the game!

The game board has two sides. One side is an addition game. The other side is a subtraction game. The instructions are the same for both sides.

Name: Curious George Finds the Bunnies Game
Description:
Curious George Finds the Bunnies Board Game starring everyone's favorite classic monkey!

Curious George let the bunnies out of their cage!
Help George look under tree stumps, rocks and bunches of flowers to find the bunnies... and remember where they are hiding until it's time to round them all up!

Name: Tangled Tales Starter Set: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 1 – Nightmare Unleashed Adventure Deck
Description:
This cool, new hand-held electronic reading game lets kids determine the outcome of their favorite stories by choosing what path the characters will take. Kids can make the game different every time they play!

Includes a deck of 79 original story cards and a deck of ten Easter egg story cards, one memory card and instructions.

Expanded by:

    Tangled Tales: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 2 â€“ The Dungeon of Havenrock Adventure Deck
    Tangled Tales: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 3 â€“ Pirates of the Black Grotto Adventure Deck
    Tangled Tales: Nancy Drew â€“ Mummy's the Word Adventure Deck
    Tangled Tales: Edgar & Ellen â€“ The Eerie Wax Museum Adventure Deck

Name: Tangled Tales: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 2 – The Dungeon of Havenrock Adventure Deck
Description:
The second part of the Gatekeeper Chronicles (Part 1 is included free with the Starter set)

The story so far...

Long ago, the evil wizard Null was trapped inside a magic book. Now he's sent his monstrous servants to find the artifacts he needs to escape his prison and destroy the world. Only you can stop him! You are a Gatekeeper, granted the power to travel into books!

Chapter 2: The Dungeon of Havenrock

The Staff of Power lies buried deep within an ancient castle built by Dwarves, Elves and Men. Null's horrible monsters swarm the abandoned citadel in search of this magical Staff. Can you dodge dragons, traps and deadly tentacles to find the prize before they do?

Also includes 10 Bonus cards from the secret chapter of the Gatekeeper Chronicles! Combine with secret cards from the Starter Set and   Tangled Tales: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 3 â€“ Pirates of the Black Grotto Adventure Deck to see how the Chronicles end!

Expands:

    Tangled Tales Starter Set: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 1 â€“ Nightmare Unleashed Adventure Deck

Name: Peanut Butter & Jelly Math
Description:
This is an educations kids game to help develop math skills. The goal for each player is to roll the die and moves their game piece around the board. Every time you pass the "Start" space, you earn a sandwich layer. The first player to go around the board four times completes his or her sandwich and winds the game.

Each space on the board contains four math problems. If the player is going around the board for the first time, he/she must solve problem #1 - or the problem next to the first small picture of bread. If he/shee is going around the board for the second time, he/she must solve problem #2 - or the problem next to the small picture of Peanut Butter, and so on.

All the game pieces (including the die) are made of a strong foam material.

Name: Big Dumb Five
Description:
Players begin with 12 stones and must secretly wager 1 to 5 stones each round.  The player with the largest unmatched bet wins all bets.  If there are no unmatched bets, the pot carries over to the next round.  When one player runs out of stones, the player with the most stones wins the game.

Big Dumb Five was published in the Origins 2000 Preregistration Book as Jump and has also appeared on the Cheapass website and in their printed catalog.  It is included in Chief Herman's Holiday Fun Pack.

Name: Yosemite Sam's Treasure Hunt Game
Description:
Simple spin-and-(not always)move game.

Players start with an equal amount of gold coins.  Coins are won and lost via directions on gameboard spaces as the 'treasure hunt' progresses.  The player with the most coins at the end of the game is the winner.

Plastic generic movers.  Thin card press-out money & spinner.  Bright, colorful gameboard & box art featuring Sam, Bugs, Fudd and various associated Looney Tunes characters.

This game is very similar to Hey, Hey, Witch Way?!

Name: ITN News at Ten: the Game
Description:
From the back of the box:

"The aim of the game is to be the first player to travel the world and put together the ITN News at Ten Program  by collecting stories in each of six categories and returning to ITN House in London. The categories are Current Affairs Home, Current Affairs Abroad, Royal, Human Interest, Sports and "...And Finally".

To collect a story players have to collect a headline card, a picture card and a story card which the majority of other players consider satisfies the category. But beware, other players can stop your story with a "Commercial Break" or a story can be stolen with an "Editor Card"."

Note: It's actually spin-and-move, not roll-and-move, but they're functionally identical.

Name: Tangled Tales: Nancy Drew – Mummy's the Word Adventure Deck
Description:
Step into the shoes of Nancy Drew, girl detective...

As a volunteer tour guide for the River Heights Cultural Museum, you've made sure everything is locked up safe and sound for the night. But being the meticulous Nancy Drew, you can't help but take another look around... and stumble right into a mystery!

When you discover a priceless gold statue from the new Egyptian Wing in a place it doesn't belong, all of your "girl detective" instincts kick in. Something is wrong! You begin investigating, but with a storm raging outside, the dark, closed museum becomes an eerie place to be. The ancient artifacts cast sinister shadows. There are strange, echoing sounds all around... and even stranger footprints!

Can you make your way through a creepy world of mummies and jackals to uncover the clues needed to solve the case... and catch a criminal?

Expands:

    Tangled Tales Starter Set: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 1 â€“ Nightmare Unleashed Adventure Deck

Name: Tangled Tales: Edgar & Ellen – The Eerie Wax Museum Adventure Deck
Description:
Edgar & Ellen are troublesome twins who live with their unusual pet, Pet, in a towering, bleak house on the outskirts of the impossibly pleasant town of Nod's Limbs. Pale-faced and clad in tattered footie pajamas, this crafty duo loves to make mischief wherever they go.

Tangled Tales Edgar and Ellen Adventure Deck - The Eerie Wax Mystery
The abandoned Waxworks on the edge of Nod's Limbs holds more than crusty vats and old machinery - strange new plants have taken root in the waxy ruins. When Edgar & Ellen and Pet sneak inside to find a giant snapping plant for Ellen's greenhouse, they stumble upon hideous oozy creatures who've started up the factory again. Mischief is afoot!

You decide what Edgar & Ellen do! Follow the clues to seek out the rare snapping plant... before the wax monsters - or something worse - can get them!

Expands:

    Tangled Tales Starter Set: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 1 â€“ Nightmare Unleashed Adventure Deck

Name: Tangled Tales: The Gatekeeper Chronicles 3 – Pirates of the Black Grotto Adventure Deck
Description:
The third part of the Gatekeeper Chronicles (Part 1 is included free with the Starter set)

The story so far...

Long ago, the evil wizard Null was trapped inside a magic book. Now he's sent his monstrous servants to find the artifacts he needs to escape his prison and destroy the world. Only you can stop him! You are a Gatekeeper, granted the power to travel into books!

Chapter 3: Pirates of Havenrock

Sail into a world of adventure! Phantom pirates terrorize the seas,brought to life by the power of a magical Hand. When Null decides to steal the Hand's power for himself, it's up to you to find it before Null's monsters do - but beware! The blood-thirsty pirates who guard the Hand won't give it up without a fight!

Also includes 10 Bonus cards from the secret chapter of the Gatekeeper Chronicles! Combine with secret cards from the Starter Set and Booster 2: The Dungeon of Havenrock to see how the Chronicles end!

Name: Schweizer Reise
Description:
Tour of Switzerland with super adventures
exciting dice game for 2-6 adventurous travelers from 8 years of age.

12 destinations are drawn before each game to provide a new and interesting route through the whole of Switzerland.  On the journey players collect as many granite and gold pieces as possible.  Granite is given to the first player to reach the destination by luck of the dice and tactics.  Players who then guess or bluff correctly the <Population>, <Height above sea level>, <Canton and geographic position>, <Places of interest and history> or <Family activities> get more granite pieces.  If you aim to hight, however, you may lose what you have already won.  You can experience super adventures on the way to advance more quickly and get more granite pieces.  The player holding the most granite and gold pieces at the end is the winner"

Name: Histamiini-peli
Description: Find the three Klip-klop-klop-tokens representing your color and get back home before anybody else in order to win.

Name: Negamco Pro Football
Description: Charts and spinner based statistical replay of Pro football.  New player ratings available each year.  Included are 13 running plays and 8 passing plays.

Name: Mad Anthony: War for Ohio, 1791-94
Description:
Boots uses an interactive game turn in which both players command an overall force made up of several sub-commands. During each turn, players alternate picking "command markers," which designate the sub-command within their force they may then use to conduct operations. The player then moves units of that sub-command and, at the completion of its movement, may conduct attacks with the units of that same sub-command. Play then passes to the other player, who similarly picks a marker and moves and fights. That procedure continues until all command markers have been picked. Additionally, certain events cause players to pick "heroism markers" at random, which may generate anything from mad, impetuous charges to abject surrenders.

The rules are divided into the standard rules, which are common to all games in the system, and the scenario rules, which provide deployment and reinforcement instructions, as well as victory conditions, for each specific battle game.

In this game, each turn represents between one week and one month, depending on the time of year, and each hexagon on the map represents 10 miles across. Units of maneuver for the US Army are primarily battalions, while Indian units are warbands, awarded one strength point for each 80 to 120 individuals within them.

Low complexity, 280 counters.
Families: Series: They Died With Their Boots On (Decision Games)

Name: Combinatorix
Description:
Features 17 multi-player games. Four years in development, this set is also a resource for tessellations and explorations of geometric plane tiling.

Contains 512 wood tiles: Squares, equilateral triangles, hexagons, and isosceles right triangles have 1" unit sides, are 1/4" thick, and in four colors. Includes three large vinyl game grids and 3 books for competitive, solo and cooperative activities. Comes in a wood chest, 26" x 14" x 3".

For 1 to 27 players, ages 6 to adult.

Name: Autoweek Trivia Game
Description: Automotive world trivia game. Roll and move around a short race track, answering questions about Races and Drivers, Automart, New and Used cars, and Autoerotica.

Name: Orient Express: 5 Nieuwe Mysteries
Description:
This expansion to the Jumbo edition of the "Orient Express" base game offers 5 new atmospheric cases to solve, all written by Ben Leijten, who was also the man behind the cases for the Jumbo base set:

JUMBO 11) "De Tiende Penning" (der zehnte/the tenth penny)
JUMBO 12) "Lov'lier Olliver" (anagramme waren seine leidenschaft)
JUMBO 13) "De Wasbeurt" (katzenwaesche/the washing schedule)
JUMBO 14) "Dressed to Kill" (der tod kam beim mummenschanz)
JUMBO 15) "Een Aasgier Geveld" (der tod des geiers/a vulture is slain)

Publishing History: "Orient Express" first appeared in the USA in 1985, published by Just Games and was quickly picked up by Jumbo NL which released a reworked version for the European market one year later. The main difference between the two editions is that the European interpretation is much more co-operative as a lot of the information is shared by all, making it a more open, but somehow also a faster and more atmospheric experience for all involved.

Since there were only 10 solvable cases that came with the base game, it was inevitable that additional cases had to be published to keep its players' base entertained. Both publishers happily obliged, each releasing their own additional sets. Jumbo only released 5 extra cases that appeared in Dutch, French, Italian and German, meaning that not all of their European language editions saw additional cases beyond the initial 10. And like before, the murders are pretty tough cases to crack, as even with all the available information revealed, some educated guesses willstill have to be made by the competing sleuths.

Name: Oh-No-Ah
Description: Noah and his three sons are assigned two pairs of animals each and are attempting to securely bring them back to the ark. The flooding is in full force and it is a race against time to complete the loading of the arc with the help of rafts and smart moves on land.

Name: Big Bigger Biggest
Description:
Children's card game (box says ages 5-8).  Cards show four animals in three different sizes (Small, Medium, and Large), plus a few extra cards (a jumbo version of each animal and jokers).  On a turn, players try to play a card to the table which shows animals that are at least as large as what's been played there before.  If not, they draw a new card.  If they play a jumbo (thus killing the chain), they get to play an extra card.  First player out of cards wins.

Note: this game gives full name credit to the two "authors" (Yehuda Harpaz and Sahar Klein).  The person credited with "design" is Hermann Wernhard.

Contents: 54 animal cards, 4 jumbo cards, 2 joker cards, Game Rules.

Ravensburger Game No. 00 631 1

Name: Legends Of Hockey
Description:
Both players move their hockey players' cards along the "ice" (game board) to set up shots, check other players, incur penalties, avoid offsides, pass the puck, etc. Everything capable in a real hockey game. Includes 90 accurately portrayed ice hockey all-stars from throughout NHL history to the present.

Contents:
1 - Game board (in three sections)
90 - Hockey player cards (54 forwards, 25 defensemen, 11 goaltenders)
4 - Six-sided dice
12 - Card stands (Two sets of 6)
1 - Puck
1 - Set-up & Summary sheet
1 - Rules sheet
1 - Cover sheet
1 - Dry erase marker

Name: Giant Intergalactic Electronic Game Book
Description:
From Back Cover - "Six great games packed into one giant book. Press the buttons and move your space travelers along the game paths in an all-out race to be the first one home! With six giant games to choose from, you can play them all in a row, or pick your favorites and play them over and over again!"

This is a collection of 6 original roll and move games laid out in a large book that unfolds to about 24"x36" of each game. 
The games are 'Space Drain', 'Deep Freeze', 'Space Splash', 'Intergalactic Games', 'Air Lock', and 'Zoom'.
The rolling is handled by an electronic device attached to the book. Players push a button and the device makes sounds and gives a number, color, or symbol depending on the game being played. In one game the device will give additional information to the player on whether a door is locked or unlocked. The game also comes with 4 little space aliens to represent the players.

Name: Twenty-Five
Description: A very popular card game in Ireland. A trick-taking game with   fairly complex ranking rules of cards depending on what suit is trump. Typically players will post an ante to the pot to start a hand. The goal is to be the first to take 5 tricks and win the pot.

Name: Street Fighter II- World Warriors Card Game
Description:
Street Fighter II- World Warriors Card Game was a spin-off of the popular 1991 game of the same name.

The game starts with the deck being dealt out evenly between players, and then split into even piles to form a "Life Bar".   One of the piles is used as your hand.  The game is a slight variant on "War"... the active player chooses an opponent, they both lay down their cards, and the higher number wins.  There are a few cards that modify the number on your card, but that's really the only variation.

The artwork on the cards is from the GI Joe Street Fighter line. Several characters look nothing like they do in the game (Ken in particular), and E. Honda's name is misspelled on the cards as "E. Hondo."

Name: Sportfiskespelet
Description: Answer questions about fishing, if you get the answers right you get fishing-tackle to use when you move around the different fishing sites and try your luck.

Name: Bonnie Prince Charlie
Description:
A game of the Jacobite Rebellion, 1745.

Bonnie Prince Charlie is a game of movement, recruitment and battle.  It is playable in two versions, a two player game and a multi-player game.  The basic rules for the two player game are used with additions for the multi-player game.

Play occurs on a mapboard which depicts the British Isles.  Forces are represented by card pieces, the color of which indicates the Jacobites (blue) or Hanoverians (red).  Forts and artillery are also represented.

The game has a mounted board and large colorful counters - graphically well ahead of it's time when published.

Name: Taxi
Description:
Each player starts the game with one taxi and $500 (borrowed). The idea of the game is to move around the board according to the basic rules of road safety and earn money by picking up cash fares from the various taxi 'ranks'.  Once you have sufficient capital you may buy a second taxi and progress to a stage where you have enough money to convert your ordinary taxis into Supercabs.

These Supercabs give you double income from 'ranks' and double income or penalties from radio calls.

The game is won when a player has two Supercabs and is able to complete a circuit of the board, arriving at his 'base' with enough cash to repay all his accumulated debts.  The player with the greatest assets wins.

Name: Frank Hyde's Footy Game
Description:
Simulating a game of Rugby League of Australia vs England.

Spin the spinner to select a player to move.  Roll the dice, move chosen player that many squares.  Take an 'Action' card and follow instructions.  Object is to get a player over the opponents try line.

Name: Good-bye to Dengue
Description:
Good-bye to Dengue is an educational board game designed by health specialist Dr. Jeffrey Lennon, currently at Foundation University, Dumaguete City in the Philippines. The game is intended to instruct children on the environmental conditions and health practices conducive to the spread and prevention of dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Good-bye to Dengue combines traditional roll-and-move mechanics with question answering in the style of Trivial Pursuit. Board spaces represent practices (e.g., covering water containers), symptoms (e.g., a rash), and stages of the mosquito life cycle (egg, larva, pupa, adult). Players gain extra turns for answering questions correctly (for example, "are the mosquitoes that transmit dengue and malaria the same?"

Good-bye to Dengue originally appeared in an unpublished 1996 manuscript written by Lennon and titled, "Health education and control of dengue hemorrhagic fever for schools and communities." The game was later reprinted as appendices K through N of Lennon's 2001 doctoral dissertation (Univ. Alabama at Birmingham) titled The Utility of a Board Game for Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever Health Education. The dissertation is available through UMI Microform (number 3040921).

Name: Bite Me
Description:
Score the most points by collecting sets of 3 and avoid the 'Bite Me' card. You obtain cards from other players by asking them for specific cards, by incorporating the words on the card in a sentence, phrase, question, etc....Example: You have a Clueless card and ask someone for theirs, by saying: You are so clueless about women. If you do not have the card being asked, but have the 'Bite Me' card, you can pass that to the person.

Includes 61 cards and instructions.

Name: Puppy Lake
Description:
A game of saving adorable puppies for 1-3 players.

The basic Puppy Lake game is a solitaire game involving puppies, a lake, Mean Old Man Hubbard, a truck, a canoe and still more puppies. Players must attempt to maneuver their canoe to save as many puppies as possible before they drown.

Mean Old Man Hubbard drives his truck back and forth across a bridge, tossing puppies into the lake. Puppies float downstream towards certain death. The player has limited control over how far he or she can paddle the canoe each turn.

Rules for 2-3 players include multiple canoes and even a Mean Old Player option.

Puppy Lake is a quick playing humorous game about a sad and serious subject. Not intended for impressionable youth.

Name: Fart The Game
Description:
You guessed it. Farting on command is a rare act to be nurtured. At its best, the act blossoms into a rich symphony of sound along with the expulsion of powerful gases ripe with pungent odors.

Roll the die to move. When a you land on a square that says drink, drink. When you land on a square that says eat beans, you may of course substitute an obnoxious substitute that causes gas. When landing on a square that directs you to fart, you will have two minutes to summon up your best effort. The other players decide how you score on the fart meter on the game board. You will then be awarded the appropriate number of gas coupons. Winning the game is done in one of two ways. 1) First person to score 25 gas coupons or 2) Let rip with such a powerful fart that you clear the whole room!

Name: Road Trip Quizwit
Description:
This is a travel version of Patch Products Tiny Tins Quizwit game.  The game consists of a magnetized board with six pawns and a pack of cards containing 1000 questions.

The game is a standard trivia game where players take turns answering trivia questions in one of three formats: 1) Multiple Choice 2) True/False 3) standard Question and Answer.  Correct answers allow you to move forward with the first player reaching the finish line being declared the winner.

There are currently three editions:

Hollywood Flicks -- questions about movies
TV Tube -- questions about TV
Top Tunes -- questions about pop music

Name: Wet Head
Description:
From the Manufacturer:
A game of water roulette! 1) Strap on the water filled Wet Head; 2) Spin the top and pull out any one of the rods; 3) If you stay dry, pass Wet Head to the next player. Make Wet Head the perfect game for any season by adjusting the amount of water you use to play. Fill Wet Head to the brim when outside in the summer heat. Bring the fun indoors for winter by using a minimal amount of water. Summer or winter, the questions remains the same, "Will you be the next Wet Head?" Wethead has become a trending sensation during the Spring of 2016, being relicensed by Rudell Design LLC and relaunched by Zing Toys, worldwide. A free downloadable app offers questions that players can be asked to determine whether or not they are required to spin a spinner (provided) to see how many rods they must remove from the hat.

Name: Africa 1483
Description:
Africa 1483 is both a stand alone game and expansion for Europe 1483. Can be combined with Europe 1483 game map to allow up to 46 players in a single game. 
Comes with a 40" x 24" color game map, rule booklet, 324 plastic playing tokens, 1D10 and territory control markers.

Name: Incorporated
Description: A game of corporate in-fighting, playable with a standard piecepack.  Players are middle managers in a large corporation who must cooperate to complete a series of corporate initiatives.  However, they want sole credit for initiatives that succeed and they want others to take the blame for initiative that fail.  If too many initiatives fail, the company goes under and everyone loses.

Name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Ready for Battle Game
Description:
This game is a simplistic "spin-and-move" for kids based on Eastman and Laird's Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles comic/tv/movie franchise.

Production quality for the TMNT Ready for Battle game ranges from good (quality of the illustrations and a good, functional spinner) to poor (lots of poor die-cutting on the cheap-feeling cardboard pieces, and an even cheaper-feeling box).

The object of the game is to collect two each of pizza and weapons tokens, and then reach the finish space to get your designated "bad guy".

Each player starts as either Michaelangelo, Donatello, Raphael or Leonardo, and chooses the matching Battle Card.  Each Battle Card has two spaces each for pizza and weapons tokens, and a designated bad guy.  The bad guys actually are just decoration, as they all wait together in the "hideout", which is part of the finish space.

Game play proceeds with each player spinning the spinner, advancing to the next space on single, linear path from start to finish that has the same color as the one just spun, and collecting either the pizza or weapon token found there.

The linear path is on a a nicely illustrated 15" x 15" board, with clearly labeled "Start" and "Finish" spaces.  There are 12 pizza spaces, 11 weapons spaces and two special "Splinter" spaces (Splinter is the benevolent rat master from the comics/tv/movies.)  The Splinter spaces allow for a "redo" if a player has yet to collect the needed tokens before advancing to the finish space.

In summary, a very, very simplistic roll-and-move style game for die-hard fans of the game.  The box states "4 and up", but I imagine beyond 6 years a child would bore of the gameplay itself.  Nice theme presentation, but very little game.
Families: Comic Books: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles

Name: WCW Thunder Card Game
Description: Players try to match the symbol on their Wrestler card with the symbol on the Action card.  The more matches you make, the more cards or points you score.

Name: The Weird-Ohs Game
Description:
The Weird-Ohs Game, Ideal, 1964.

Theme based on the Hawk Model Co. Model Kits, "The Weird-Ohs", which were hot-rod designs by William "Bill" Campbell.  (Similar to the drag-racing monster-like characters of Ed "Big Daddy" Roth and Stanley Mouse).

These were a huge hit in 1963/64, and this game follows their theme.  (Some may remember this as a cartoon from the late 90's with different artwork.)

A spin-the-spinner and move game, with some event cards thrown-in.

Terrific, colorful artwork.

Name: Murder at the Four Deuces Teen
Description:
from the publisher's website:

Murder At The Four Deuces is a 1920's gangster murder mystery game with a murder, bribery and back stabbing to be had. Some of the guests will include gangsters, politicians, singers and gamblers.

Don and MeMe Wannabe are hosting the grand opening celebration of their new club The Four Deuces and you are invited to attend. The Four Deuces is a lavish juice joint serving music, food & fun. The cream and not so cream of society will be here. With gangsters, politicians, dolls, molls and many other interesting guests in attendance this event is sure to be the bee's knees.

Game content rating:

We have taken our bestselling murder mystery game Murder at the Four Deuces and tweaked it to be suitable for teens and/or adults who are concerned about the content in the Mature version.

This version has no prostitution. In keeping with the TEEN rating there are characters who secretly see others, but they are not called affairs. The murder takes place at the party. Everything is done very tastefully so as not to offend.

Name: Sneak a Peek (The Crossword Game)
Description: Sneak A Peek (The Crossword Game) is a game where players interactively solve actual themed crossword puzzles, but with many exciting twists. Each player receives different clues based on the draw of a card and roll of a die. They may answer for points or receive a free sneak a peek letter anywhere on the puzzle board. As the game progresses, the board is filling in, players are amassing (and now know the answers to) many clues, and point values and heart rates are escalating. Add in double, triple, and wild cards, as well as players loaded with sneak a peek letters, and you have an exhilarating race to the final solution of every puzzle.

Name: Flocks
Description: The wild and wacky game of memory and luck. Collect the most Flocks from the twenty-one different types of bird cards, but beware! This daft and daffy game also also has the Spying Spectacle Bird that allows you to look at other players' cards and the Crazy Cuckoo Bird that lets you grab someone else's Flocks.

Name: Ramesses' War
Description:
From the Publisher's Web Site:

Ramesses' War is a two player board game covering the ancient war between Egypt and the Hittite Empire. During the later stages of the Hittite Empire, circa 1400 BC to 1250 BC, the Hittite Empire had recovered from a period of weakness where it had been on constant warfare with the Arzawa and Mittani states. By 1290 BC the Hittites had managed to conquer Arzawa entirely and had captured the Mitanni capital, though elements of the Mittani people still resisted the further advances of the Hittites. Further, the Hittites had moved into the northern Palestinian region and had come to dominate Syria. This led to friction between the Hittites and the Egyptian, who themselves held large parts of Palestine and had ruled there for more than two centuries. Historically the showdown between these two powers culminated in the battle at Kadesh, initiated by Ramesses who had rallied Egyptian military might in order to directly challenge further Hittite expansion.

Ramesses' War is an easy to play two player game that lets you revisit that ancient conflict. However, the map provided expands the conflict to also encompass the various regional powers. Troy, an ally of the Hittites, plus Lukka, the Mittani and Ahhiyawa (Most probably the Hittite name for the Mycenaean Greeks), as well as providing units for an Arzawan rebellion and troops for each Palestinian city state.

The Ramesses' War Includes:

     2 piece, 17" × 22" color game map
     37 Full-Color Hittite Counters
     9 Full-Color Trojan Counters
     8 Full-Color Arzawan Counters
     4 Full-Color Lukka Counters
     11 Full-Color Ahhiyawa Counters
     37 Full-Color Egyptian Counters
     7 Full-Color Mittani Counters
     23 Assorted Full-Color Palestinian Counters
     Game Rules
     D10
     4½" × 5¾" × 1½" Game Box
Families: History: Wars in the Ancient Near East
Series: Compact Game Series (Guild of Blades)

Name: Pantheons
Description: Each player in this game controls a Pantheon chosen from a list that includes the Greeks, Norse, Egyptians, Celts, Babylonians and so on, and tries to conquer the world for their respective pantheon.  Along the way, players can develop new mystical abilities and recruit interloper factions (such as the forces of Heaven or Hell) to help lead their armies into battle. Pantheon features three kinds of game units (Infantry, Heroes, and Gods), with each Hero and God unit for the respective pantheons having their own names and stats. This game includes one set of game rules, a 17" x 44" four-piece black & white map, 1D10, and over 1000 cut-out counters.

Name: Africa's 30 Year War: Chad Vs. Libya – The Toyota War
Description: In this game, players take control of Libya, Chad, the French Foreign Legion, Sudan Militants or the Islamic Legion and re-fight the Toyota War between Chad and Libya. This game includes a 17" x 22" four piece game map on quality index card stock, 216 tokens, 216 stickers for the tokens, 1D10, game rule & scenario booklet, and nation score sheet.
Families: Series: Obscure Wars Series (Guild of Blades)

Name: Kotu Elima
Description:
Kotu Elima originates from Sri Lanka and is (in similar versions) also played in India and Indonesia. The "Leopard Game" is a so called South Asian Siege Game. 2 leopards attack 24 cows.  For this reason it is well-known also under the name of "Cows and Leopards".

2 strategy games on one board:

Kotu Elima:  Each player has 24 marbles. Goal is it to strike the opposing stones by jumping over them.

Leopard Game:  First the marbles are set, then alternating one player pulls.  The cows win, if the leopards cannot pull any longer, the leopards win, if they struck 8 cows.

Name: The War to End All Wars: The Great War in Africa
Description:
This is an expansion to The War to End All Wars: Box Set Edition that can be played as a stand-alone game or combined with the base game.  The game comes with a 17" x 22" map of central and southern Africa, an 11" x 17" black & white map of South America, a 16 page Rule & Scenario booklet, a score pad with 30 nation sheets, 1D10, around 120 plastic unit stands, card stock land & sea units for: 
 -- British Colonies & Empire 
 -- French Colonies & Empire 
  -- German Colonies & Empire 
 -- Belgian Congo 
 -- Portuguese Colonies 
 -- Argentina 
 -- Brazil 
 -- Neutrals 
 -- Ports, Ind. Complexes, Trenches, & Misc. 
 -- Generals, Resource Chits, Incorp. Markers

Expands:

    The War to End All Wars: Box Set Edition
Families: Game: War to End All Wars

Name: Kaiju Moon
Description: Kaiju Moon is an expansion for Kaiju: Giant Monster Boardgame that can also be played as a stand-alone game.  In it, players take on the roles of the United Nations Moon Base forces, the Moon Men, the Evil Caucasians from The Future or the mighty Kaiju Destroyers and compete for dominion of the Moon.  When combined with the base game, Kaiju can support up to eight players.  This game includes an 11" x 17" two piece mapboard, game rules, 1D10, 75 tokens, and some Destroyer and Champion cut-out units.

Name: Fallen Blackhawk: Somalia
Description: This game recreates the "Blackhawk Down" conflict of the early nineties in Somalia between the US forces and the forces of the Somali warlord Adid.  As the US Army Rangers and Special Forces, your troops are stranded in the middle of a hostile city, and you will have to fight your way back to the US army base, with what little assistance from the air you can receive. As the warlord Adid, your goal is to kill the US soldiers  before they can escape.  This game includes a 2 piece, 17" x 33" map, 134 counters, game rules, and 1D10.
Families: Series: Compact Game Series (Guild of Blades)

Name: 3D5
Description:
3D5 by the Lolo Company is essentially a 3D Tic-Tac-Toe game played in a 5x5x5 cube, allowing 109 possible winning combinations.

The one twist relative to a simple 5 in a row Tic-Tac-Toe game is that the center space of the cube is a "free" space, that can  contribute to five in a row for either player. Optionally, players may specify up to nine additional free spaces beyond the center space as part of the set-up (game can with 10 neutral marbles).

An interesting feature of this game is that it comes with a set of tweezers to manipulate the balls in the grid. The grid levels are only about 2 inches apart.

Another odd feature is the posts that separate the layers. There are spacers between the layers with an elastic running through the center of the posts. Thus you can rotate the layers of the game and get it fold. There is a special peg provided to screw into the bottom tray holding the marbles to keep the game folded.

Name: Bravo Piepino!
Description:
The little birds just want to get home to their warm, cozy nest. Move for move, the feather cards show how far the birds can fly in one go. Oops! There's something strange about these cards! Every now and again the bird hop, seemingly on their own, one space forward  or one space back. The birds and some cards are magnetic. The first bird to land in its nest is the winner.

Ages 4 and up.

Name: King
Description:
Invented by an ex-Durham shipyard worker, King combines elements of tic, tac, toe with the 'Kings Move' from Chess.

The objective of the game is to move your 3 pieces one by one around a 3x3 grid until you win by getting all 3 in a row.

Initial placement: Take turns placing pieces on the board until all 6 are out, the first piece cannot be placed in the center.

Movement: Take turns moving one piece one square in any direction (except diagonally black-to-black). No taking/jumping allowed.

Name: Krazy Bee Bowling
Description:
Each player is dealt 10 cards.  Each frame a player will draw one card from the deck and play one or two cards.  A player can draw cards to complete the 10th frame.  A player may draw more than one card to complete his or her frame.  If a player has a Spare card in hard when the 10th frame is completed, it will count 10 point off for every Spare card in hand, as well as the face value of the number cards.  The player with the highest score after penalty cards are deducted  from the 10th frame is declared the winner.

The game is produced by B & B Games, Inc. of Midwest City, Oklahoma.  According to a game insert, Bill Weingartner appears to be the designer and/or publisher.

Name: Feilong
Description:
From publisher`s website:

Feilong (pronounced fay-loong) is a question-based game designed for players with limited, intermediate, as well as extensive knowledge of China. Its three decks of question cards are arranged in three levels of difficulty. Players with a very limited or a Beginner's level of knowledge play the game with Deck A; Intermediates with Decks A & B; and, Experts with Decks A, B & C. The game's goal is to stimulate curiosity and encourage all players to eventually "graduate" to playing Feilong with all three decks.

TO PLAY

Players start by deciding if the game will be played by the rules for Beginners, Intermediates, or Experts. They then select one of the "Tours in Time & Space" listed in the Rules Folder and enter the chosen tour's eight destination numbers (i.e., space numbers on the game board's playing track) in the blocks at the top of the Score Pad. Players advance around the playing track by correctly answering questions and outwitting opponents that exploit the game's strategy options. The first player to "visit" (i.e., land on the space of) each of the tour's eight destinations and enter the map of China in the center of the board wins the game.

Name: Walt Disney Productions' Robin Hood Game
Description:
One day Prince John decides to raise the taxes on all the people of Nottingham.  So he sends the Sheriff of Nottingham and his men out to collect the taxes.  After the Sheriff has collected the taxes he returns to Prince John's castle and places all the gold in Prince John's treasure room.  The people of Nottingham are already poor and many of them are left with no money at all after paying their taxes.  The poor people send a message telling of the new tax to Robin Hood and his band of merry men who live deep in the heart of Sherwood Forest......

Based on the Disney production of Robin Hood.  Each player selects a character (Robin Hood, Little John, Friar Tuck or Maid Marion).  The first person to get the bag of gold from Prince John and return to Robin's Forest Hideout is the winner.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Robin Hood

Name: The Wonderful World of Disney
Description:
Each player takes the role of a Disney character (Mickey, Thumper, Donald, Bambi, Perdita, Winnie, Dumbo or Jiminy).  Play commences with a view to collecting tokens representing the different characters and 'Disney Awards'.

Multiple Disney Awards are obtained each turn by selling tokens.  Tokens can be purchased at the end of each player's turn by way of a general auction for Disney Awards....

The first player to obtain one token of every color (8) and 12 or more 'Disney Awards' is the winner.

Name: Asiphile
Description: Created by a South African Playwright to teach children about the dangers of AIDS.  The title of the game means "Let Us Live"

Name: Holidaze
Description:
This game simulates the nightmarish rush to successfully complete one's shopping in the thick of the traffic surrounding the Xmas season.  The objective is to be the first player to successfully complete your shopping and work your way through the traffic to the finish line.  Along the way, you have the chance to increase your Xmas "Joy" and add to your opponents woes through by drawing and playing "Joy" and "Bah Humbug" cards, among others.

This game is a sister game to "Orange Barrels."  If interested in learning more, you can inquire at the designer's site:
http://www.orangebarrelsthegame.com/

Name: Longhorn
Description:
You play a "trail boss" working for a ranching outfit and your job is to drive a herd of cattle to market and well them at the best price.  You start off with 12 cowboys, 500 head of cattle (and can hunt for more), and head north, driving your herd over the long, dusty miles to Kansas.  You'll have lots to deal with along the way, but with a bit of luck and cool judgment, you'll make a handsome profit at the end of the drive.
      The game board shows Texas, the Indian Territory (modern Oklahoma) and Kansas, along with parts of other states and territories as the were in the early 1870's. Several cattle trails important in the early 1870's are shown, although many more trails, especially in south central Texas were used at different times.

Name: Tenacity
Description: On an oval "400" meter Tenacity track, each player starts at the Hometown space and strives to end at the podium space where a roll of the die will determine which medal--gold, silver, bronze--they have won. Medals are included and must be placed around the winner's neck by the player on the right while others applaud and yell in support. Along the track there are sponsors, money and many miscellaneous gains and setbacks on the way to the winners' podium. Also included are clip-on athletes' passes and gold-colored metal playing pieces that represent different sports. Instructions, beside being on the inside of the box lid, are also included on a cassette tape.

Name: The Gold Rush
Description: Players recreate the California Gold Rush of 1848-1849, exploring the Sierra Nevada Mountains, staking claims and panning for gold.  The winner is the player who can extract the most gold in excess of his expenditures to obtain it.  Players must be careful, as they can even be killed in their efforts.

Name: Wall Street Up/Down
Description:
From the publisher's website: Like Monopoly, a toss of the dice moves your game piece along the board’s squares. That same toss sends stock and bond prices up or down, sometimes soaring, sometimes plummeting; always seemingly predictable, but therein —like the real stock markets—lies its drama.

The square where your game piece lands determines your play-opportunities. The headlines of the game’s mini-newspaper—the “Wall Street News”—sets that round’s “general” direction of stock prices, up or down —but (like the real markets) when stock prices climb, bond prices are more apt to fall.

Like a surfer reads the waves, you win at this game of daring, intuitiveness and strategy, by reading the market’s clues and riding the crests of the market’s seven moods.

Name: Cross Card
Description:
"No bad card will exist.
But one failure, the next one will laugh.
You need the right turn at the right time in this hot mixture of Card and Board game." (written on the Box)

Every Player try, with playing one card/Round  on the Board, to finish 5 in a row. At the End of game you get the points.
You get different Points with
Pairs
two pairs
triples
"Poker"
"Flush"
"Streets"
"Full House"
...

A quick game with short rules.

Name: Attention!
Description:
An early and original abstract game for 2 to 4 players, heavily influenced by "Halma / Chinese Checkers" and "Draughts" and meant to fill the challenge-gap between "Draughts" and "Chess".

The board depicts three pyramids of 23 fields each (the 3- and 5-layer appear twice). These pyramids touch each other at the tips in the very center of the board, and are angled in such a way that a hexagonal playing area is created. One player occupies the top 6 fields of each pyramid at the center of the board with 18 black pawns. The remaining pawns are placed on the two base-rows of each pyramid, 10 pawns in 3 colors, one color for each pyramid.

One player plays the beleaguered black pawns and tries to eliminate all other pieces. The remaining player(s) try to occupy one of the 3 center fields with a pawn in their color. The 3-player game is a bit contrived as one player will play 2 outer colors.

Pieces move like draught-pieces: they either move one space or capture a piece by hopping over it to a free field behind it. Pawns from the outer colors can only move or capture sideways or towards the board center (sideways to a neighboring pyramid is also possible). Outer pieces can capture only the black pawns with the same direction restrictions. The black pawns can capture any of the other colors in all directions. A player isn't obliged to capture.

In the opening move the outer colors start, opening with two different pawns per color, then the inner player moves one pawn from each pyramid. From then on, outer colors play one of their pawns in sequence, then the black player can play as many different black pawns as there are outer colors left in play, and these do no longer have to belong to different pyramids. If a player cannot move the turn moves on to the next player in line. Play continues until a victory condition is met.

Publication history: the game originally appeared in 1897 as Ravensburger Spiel Nr. 63 and made a bit of gaming history when it was released. Up until that point Otto Maier had been publishing only classic and widely known games as "Chess", "Halma" and "Reversi". This was the first time he published an original abstract boardgame through his now famous games imprint.

He quickly discovered all the obstacles to success that are still in force today: it is hard to market a game with rules that aren't commonly known, that has no promotional campaign to attract a critical mass of new players, and that has to be sold by salesmen who are unfamiliar with the game. Overall it became a learning experience, one that made him reflect a few years later when the game was withdrawn from sale after a single print-run: "abstract boardgames are harder to market than those who are underpinned by fitting themes and illustrations". This realization might have been the beginning of the paste-on theme solution of which the German (and Euro) games are so often "accused", but which does appear to have a function that is easily overlooked by the "accusers". Themes draw buyers in, and rules are easier to explain when there is a story to tell, especially to younger players.

The original edition was issued in a remarkably lavish production (for that time in the German market) with great attention to detail. Even the board and box were covered with quality imitation-leather. It then disappeared until 1983, when it was reprinted by Spielbox magazine (1983/1, jan-mar) as the sixth game in their emerging "Spiel zum Herausnehmen / Game to Remove" series.

Name: Perlen-Pyramide
Description:
"Perlen-Pyramide" or "Pearl-Pyramid"

Quick playing abstract pyramid stacking game for exactly 3 players. Each player uses a pool of 25 "pearls" in their color and placement starts on a 5x5 base grid, with pearls in subsequent layers being supported by four underneath.  A completed pyramid will thus contain exactly 55 pearl bricks.

Each player in turn will add exactly one piece to the construction, and the aim is to have the most external pearls visible in the completed pyramid. Players will be placing their pearls only onto the base of the pyramid, making sure all placed pearls touch what's already there (orthogonal or diagonally). Placement of pearls on the additional layers is triggered automatically by what is present underneath. The moment that a square group of four pearls is created in the same layer, a special "filling" placement interrupts the regular turn progression. To resolve which pearl gets placed on top of the four pearls underneath players need to look at how many different pearls are present. If one color is in the majority (3:1 or 2:1:1) then another pearl of that color gets placed on top. However, if two players each have two pearls  present than a pearl of the third player becomes the peak. If all four pearls are from a single player then the player who would have the turn after this colour's player gets to place the bonus pearl. When the bonus pearl itself triggers the completion of another group of four in the next layer then again bonus pearls are resolved before the normal turn-order is resumed. When the 25th base pearl is placed the completion of the pyramid is triggered and the game ends. The winner is the one with the most external pearls present.

Three variations are also included.

Publishing history: Peter Pallat was one of the original designer "Altmeisters" of the German game industry.  It was his designs that found their way into many family homes from way back in the 1930s, through Ravensburger, then known as Otto Maier Verlag, and others. He remained an active designer throughout his life, but his career went through a renaissance when, in his older days, he found a welcome and supportive group of younger designers and admirers, who, in their turn, had become torch-bearers of German game design. One of these, Reinhold Wittig, published a handful of Peter Pallat's games and ideas in small editions through his own Edition Perlhuhn designers imprint, giving him the recognition for his longstanding input into our hobby he fully deserved. These games later found their way to publishers like Abacus and the Danish Abra who released wooden versions of some of these. As did this game. "Perlen-Pyramide" appeared with Edition Perlhuhn in 1978 and was republished by the Danish Abra as part of their abstract wooden game series of the latter part of the 1980s. It is hard to get hold of these days.

Name: SPACE BASTARDS! From outer space!
Description:
The Galactic Wars are over. Treaties have been signed, pacts made and peace is spreading throughout the galaxy. What the hell are you supposed to do now?

Become a SPACE BASTARD! , a galactic warrior whose only claim to fame is being good at reducing other Bastards to their base molecular structures.

Rather than face the unspeakable horrors of a desk job you can cruise the galaxy meeting interesting aliens and kill them for nothing more than the glory of battle... and the skyrocketing ratings of the Galactic Network that televise their epic struggles.

SPACE BASTARDS! From outer space! Coming soon to a planet near you... perhaps you should move.

SPACE BASTARDS! is a miniatures game that pits you against your fellow players. You only need one miniature in addition to the rule book and some foolish opponents to get you started.
(Above is from the homepage)
Comes with:
rulebook
6 character sheets
3 dice
cheat sheet

Name: Annette's Secret Passage Game
Description:
Parker Brothers game from 1958. Annette, Spin and Marty are on a cruise off the coast of California with Marty's grandmother. One evening as the graceful "Sea Sprite" sails into the Blue Lagoon off the shore of Shell Island they see "Hawk the Pirate" fishing. During the night Marty's grandmother's jewels are stolen. Annette thinks that whoever stole them must have escaped to the Island. They go looking for Hawk the Pirate and the jewels

Game comes with one set of footprint cards and one set of fish cards. 4 colored playing pieces, 4 earrings, 1 boat, 4 boat cards, 4 spinners and a playing board.

Object of the game is to be the first person to reach the FINISH square with one of Hawk's earrings and a boat.

Name: Triple Play Baseball
Description:
TP Baseball gives you the opportunity to step into the shoes of your favorite team's manager and general manager and guide your team into the post-season and beyond.  Not only do you handle the on-field duties as the manager, using TP Baseball league rules lets you sign major league free agents, draft promising prospects, and make late season trades.

TP Baseball uses three ten-sided dice, and will be quickly picked up by the experienced tabletop manager.  For those of you new to the experience, the game can be easily understood by just sitting down and playing a few games.  Nothing beats the hands-on experience.  The dice create a three digit number from 000 to 999.   Review the two players cards after the roll.  Results of 000-499 are read on the hitter's card and 500-999 are read on the pitcher's card.  Most results are explained easily right on the card.  A few may need the use of an outside chart, but after playing the game a couple times, most of the results should become second nature.

Name: Hau-Hau koiravisa
Description: A trivia game about dogs.

Name: Afterworld
Description:
Panini is proud to announce Afterworld; our newest Trading Card Game.

In the Afterworld, the greatest champions from the civilizations of Atlantis, Viking legend, Ancient Egypt, and Ancient Japan are pitted against each other for dominance. With stunning original artwork and exciting gameplay, Afterworld offers players the best of both worlds, a complete and compelling game experience with the fun of chasing rare cards to enhance the experience.

Will the Atlantean commander be able to stop the Norse Commander from razing the beautiful undersea territories of Atlantis? Will the Japanese Commander be victorious in subjugating the best units from Ancient Egypt? Play Afterworld and find out.

Name: Triumvirat
Description:
Triumvirat consists of a triangular board with 28 molds and 18 spheric marbles in three colors of three sizes. In the beginning the marbles of each color are situated like this: One large in the corner, two medium sized in the two molds in front of it and three small ones in the three molds before them.

At every turn the player moves one marble, just to the next mold or jumping over other marbles, also combining a number of jumps in one move, if possible. The marbles jumped over may be taken away. Similar to Halma until here, the main difference is that the marbles can only capture marbles the same size or smaller. Because of the very limited space the game is fast and allows no false move.

Played with two players the marbles of the third color just stay at the starting position and will not be moved. The space is even more limited now ...

The first player with only one marble left, loses. The winner is the one with the most points left on the board: The big marble counts 3, the medium sized 2 and a small one 1 point.

Name: This Accursed Civil War: The Battle of Cheriton, 1644
Description: This C3i Magazine Nr17 Module by RBM Studio contains the battle-specific counters and a new mapsheet to simulate the battle of Cheriton. To play this battle module you must have the boxed game This Accursed Civil War.

Name: Kakuro for Dummies
Description: After SuDoKu for Dummies, now the Kakuro Game. Another game based on the popular Japanese puzzles.

Name: Fingerprint Expert
Description: Players roll and move around the board, trying to collect a set of ten cards representing matching right and left hand fingerprints. The cards for each hand must represent the proper fingers and have matching print pattern styles. There are wild cards to aid in building each hand.

Name: Strike Force Jove
Description:
Strike Force Jove (alternately Strike Force: Jove) is a game depicting a theoretical conflict between commercially backed mercenary forces within a region of the Jovian atmosphere. The game postulates the existence of a small area within Jupiter's atmosphere conducive to the creation of structurally primitive life-forms and highly complex chemicals which are commercially valuable in a variety of industrial processes.

It was published in Pandora magazine v1:2, and was a development from the author's Hellball game.

Name: Inter
Description: 1 board with 196 squares representing the world with continents in 7 different colors, 1 set of fortune cards, money, 1 die, playing pieces in 8 different colors each having: 1 president, 2 diplomats and 6 bases. Every player starts in a different continent. The aim of the game is to get as much influence in the world as possible. The player who erects bases in the 6 other continents wins the game.

Name: Finger-Flick Sports: Football
Description:
Description from box:

Finger-Flick Sports: Football is an incredibly exciting and interactive sports board game that mirrors the play of football itself! There's no counting spaces or rolling the dice to score. With Finger -Flick Football you run, pass, kick field goals and PAT's, make great defensive plays, and score touchdowns - all with the flick of a finger.

Finger-Flick Sports: Football has something for everyone - it's fast, exciting, challenging, and lots of fun. Best of all, this game is an enjoyable way to bring friends and families together.

Finger-Flick Sports: Football comes with everything you need for great family entertainment! And, it's easy to play - all it takes is the flick of a finger and you're in the game!

Name: Dragon Run
Description:
Dragon Run is a game of desperate combat and flying maneuver. One player takes the part of the Dragon summoned by Lord Ethamon, the dragon priest. He must reach Dragon's Tower and devour the fair maiden. The other player commands the troops loyal to King Corvallis, daring soldiers who ride upon the backs of swift, flying steeds. This player must slay the Dragon before Princess Tanis is consumed.

The heart of the game is maneuver. Each turn the Dragon secretly selects a maneuver, then watches as the wind riders choose theirs. The player who wins is often the one who can most often out-guess his or her opponent.

Published in the first issue of Pandora magazine (Volume 1, Number 1).

Name: The New Teen Choices
Description:
From the back of the box:

Making the right choice can be tough. But with the help of Teen Choices, learning to make the best decisions becomes exciting entertainment.

Grab your family and friends and get ready to come face to face with some of life's toughest decisions including those involving peer pressure, honesty, and purity. Learn how to base all your decision making on Biblical principles (twenty in all, supported by several versus from the popular NIV translation of the Bible

Includes gameboard, 6 player markers, 150 dilemma cards, 10 principle cards and instructions/reference booklet

Name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe – The Liberation of Narnia
Description:
The Liberation of Narnia uses 52 shield-shaped cards printed with photos of various characters from The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe movie. Each player arranges his 26 cards in four rows of six, face down, with the Lion and the Witch cards in a separate seventh row. Players throw the die and try to pick a card whose picture matches the symbol on the die. If the die and the card match the card is removed. The player thus tries to carve a path to uncover the Lion and win the game.

The game also contains alternate rules for Quartett/Happy Families.

There is a limited edition of this game too.
The cards are a better quality and the die is bigger and gold coloured.
All the contents are in a metal case.

Name: Euroopan Omistaja
Description: A trivia game about Europe and European Union.

Name: Naturstig
Description:
Naturstig - A game about animals and plants in our Swedish landscapes, as the box says is about moving around and knowing animals by name and where they live. One rule version for the smallest and one for those a bit more grown up.

Ravensburger no: 00 182 8

Name: Frisian Checkers
Description:
"Oer Alles" (translates as "Over All")
aka "Frysk damjen" (Frisian) or "Fries dammen" (Dutch) or "Frisian draughts" (English)

Frisian draughts is closely related to the now standard game of (Polish) draughts and can be traced back to at least the late 1600s, when the games of the Draughts Family were sweeping through Europe from the French base. It has retained its unique rules ever since, and presently has its own league, founded in 1932, and is still widely played in its natural home of Friesland. Friesland is now a province with its own language and culture in the North of the Netherlands.

The "normal" version of draughts only slowly made its way into Friesland, and is known there as "Oer Hoek" (over corners) or "Hollânsk damjen/Hollands dammen". These days you are more likely to hear people talk about "Frysk Damjen" than "Oer Hoek".

The set-up and basic movement is identical to the commonly known game, but it won't be long before the main difference will become very apparent: capturing isn't restricted to just diagonal jumps, but can be executed horizontally and vertically as well. Yes, a piece can capture in all 8 directions! If you think that makes it easier to solve, try it. It has a lot more action but it doesn't become easier.

There are other subtle variations:
A promoted King can be moved only three times in succession when a player still has normal pieces. After that it must be "released" by a capture (which can be made with the same king) or by moving another piece. When a player has nothing but Kings then this rule is ignored. When you can capture, you must, but if a King and a standard piece can both capture a stone, or stones, of equal value, then it is the King that has to make the capture. When there are multiple capturing opportunities of equal value than the one that includes most Kings must be taken. The moment a player obtains a second King (and his opponent has only one), than that player has seven moves to finish the match or it automatically becomes a draw. Kings can make long jumps.

A few more names:
The Frisians are still proud sailors and it should come as no surprise that there are more pockets along the North Sea and Baltic Sea that play the game, where it is known under many names that all refer to the erstwhile important Frisian harbour village of Molkwar/Molkwerum, famous in the Netherlands for its ad-hoc infrastructure. Early Dutch literature (mockingly) refers to Frisian draughts with its free-form any-direction capturing as "Molkwerums dammen" as an homage to the labyrinthine village.
"Molkwerums dammen" (Dutch). A similar game is "Makvær" (Danish) or "Marquern" (Swedish), however, it is played on an 8x8 board and, in Makvær, a King doesn't only move diagonally, but also orthogonally, that is in 8 directions.

And more still:
"Jeu du Dame Bablionique" (French), "Babylonian Draughts" (English)

There is even a game played in Siberia that follows very similar rules to Frisian Draughts, except that it is played on a 64 field chess board.

Name: Vega
Description:
Vega (for Children from 6 up and grown-ups) has a hexagonal board  of 54 triangles. Each player gets up to 10 tetraeders of one color as "stones" to move. Each tetraeder has one marked side. Each move consists of rolling the tetraeder three times over one of its edges and eventually block or capture an opponent`s tetraeder.
Vega has three variants, from very easy up to more strategic.

Name: H. R. Pufnstuf Game
Description:
Game is based on the trippy children's television series H. R. Pufnstuf from the late sixties.

Players must attempt to collect a single set of 4 cards which form a picture of one of the shows characters (Jimmy, Pufnstuf, Freddie, Cling/Clang) when assembled, depending on the character selected by the player at the start of the game.  Each card is duplicated once.

The 32 cards are dealt in 4 piles face down on the board in designated areas.  Gameplay is directed by a spinner.  Cards are taken up or returned to the board, or taken from opponents, depending on the spin.

The first player to collect the four correct cards that complete their character picture wins the game.

Name: Depth Charge
Description:
Earned 5th Place in the 2005 About.com and GameTable Online Deduction Game Design Contest.

Per the rules of the contest it only requires common gaming items and printed materials included with the rules.

Flavor text from the rules - “It’s time once more for naval exercises on Lake Ashtapada to test what the new crewmen have learned about using sonar. They will be split into two teams, Red and Black, who will set three targets to represent mines for each other to find. The first team to find the other’s mines wins the trophy; the other will be scrubbing toilets.”

Online Play


    Super Duper Games
